title: World's End Llangollen Walking Route

images.title: David Nulty, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Spring/ Water Up-welling. This is the point close to the path where the water that is travelling through the World's End limestone cave system wells up. If you follow the path a hundred metres or so uphill to a cave you can clearly hear the water flowing down to this spring. Although it is on a much smaller scale this is reminiscent of the way Malham Beck bubbles from the base of Malham Cove.

images.title: David Nulty, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Top Cave. This cave entrance is about 5 feet tall and you can hear falling water clearly. It is close to the path up from the World's End ford. In periods of heavy rain water can flow out of the cave entrance.

images.title: Chris Heaton / Stream at Worlds End
images.caption: Stream. Wooded dell crossed by the Offa's Dyke National Trail.

images.title: Tim Heaton / The ford at World's End
images.caption: The ford. The narrow road following the valley of the Eglwyseg River (from right) makes a sharp turn crossing the headwaters of the river before climbing up Esclusham Mountain (to left)

images.title: John Haynes / Plas Uchaf, Worlds End
images.caption:
Plas Uchaf, Worlds End. A much improved house with an attached farm going for full organic status.
Plas Uchaf, an Elizabethan half-timbered manor house, dating from 1563, which was built on the site of the 12th century hunting lodge of Owain ap Cadwgan. Another occupant was Colonel John Jones, who was the brother-in-law of Oliver Cromwell, and one of the signatories of Charles
I's death warrant. There is also a local rumour that Elizabeth I came here to give birth to an illegitimate child.

images.title: Eirian Evans / Offa's Dyke Path
images.caption: Offa's Dyke Path near the site.

images.title: Jeff Tomlinson / Ford at World's End
images.caption: The Ford. Take care here as it can be slippery.

images.title: Green crater by Ian Paterson, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Green crater and view towards the eastern end of the site.

description: Explore this beautiful narrow vale on this popular circular walk near Llangollen. The World's End Gorge is a great place for a walk with pretty streams, little waterfalls and attractive woodland. It's an atmospheric place with the area enclosed by the cliffs of Craig y Forwyn, Craig y Cythraul, and Craig yr Adar. The walk takes you through the delightful wooded gorge to the heather moors on top of the Eglwyseg Mountain. As such it's a nice varied route with wonderful views of the River Eglwyseg and the surrounding Welsh Hills with lots of interesting flora and fauna. You can start off from the public car parking area just off a country lane to the north of the site. This route is designed for walkers but the area is also popular with mountain bikers. See the video below of cyclists on the Horseshoe Pass for details! The Offa's Dyke Path runs past the area so you could pick this up and head north to the nearby Llandegla Forest . If you would like a more challenging walk then try the climb to Castell Dinas Bran . The atmospheric ruins of the medieval castle are a must see if you are visiting the area. Easier walking can be found along the towpath of the lovely Llangollen Canal . You could also start the walk from Llangollen and follow the trail through the beautiful Vale of Llangollen to World's End. Our Panorama Walk starts from the nearby famous Pontcysyllte Aqueduct and follows the scenic country road up to the site. The area is also only a few miles west of Wrexham.
